During the warm months, he operates a car washing service, charging between 2,400 and 4,000 tugrugs (1.5-2.5 USD) per car. During the winter months, he operates a skating rink and charges his customer 500 tugrugs per hour to skate. All year round, he uses his carpentry skills to make and sell wooden products. In his carpentry business, he has sales between 500,000 and 800,000 tugrugs per month with a profit of 150,000 and 250,000 tugrugs. He hopes to eventually build a large workspace where he can operate his car washing business year-round. He says: "My wife and I are young and we have many hopes and aspirations for the future." Zorigbaatar is requesting a loan of 500,000 tugrug (approx. $344 USD) in order to purchase feed for his family's livestock and carpentry equipment for his business.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his family's livestock and carpentry equipment for his business.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion G. is from Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Concepcion is married. To make a living, Concepcion owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling "copras" - dried coco meat used in making coco oil in the local community. Concepcion has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Concepcion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Concepcion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Dulce

texts.en:
Dulce D., 22, would do anything to improve the lives of her family. Married to Bribon D., a factory worker, they are blessed with one child. Even though she had a family at a young age, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn income so that they can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for five months.

Dulce has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow four times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy grocery items for her variety store. Her three businesses let her earn a combined net profit of PHP 5,500 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of PHP 10,000. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her to expand her business by buying mobile phone credits, added stock for her store, and assorted meat products.

She prays that her business will continue to grow so that one day she and her husband can have resources to buy their own house and lot and for their child to finish his studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone credits, added stock for her store, and assorted meat products.

loans.name: Nao's Group

texts.en: The village bank loan which consists of sixteen people is located in Preak Khmaer village in Kandal province. Mrs. Nao S. is the group leader who has been selected by the members and they will all use the loan for different purposes. She is a vegetable seller and her husband, Mr. Tub Yuon, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support their family. In the field, Mrs. Nao S. faces a problem because the soil is infertile, but she does not have money to purchase fertilizers. Thus, Mrs. Nao S. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers and expand her vegetable business. She is a mother of three children; one is a security guard, one is a farmer, while the other is a student in secondary school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Đăng's Group

texts.en:
H. Đặng Thị (20213010076) is a 52 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  H. is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is An Ninh nhóm 09 (An Ninh 2).

H. is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To making a living, H. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattle for sale. H. has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,704,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She is now requesting a new loan of 7,392,000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be the third loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Lê Thị D. (20213010038) is a 26 year-old female who is requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.

2.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20213010037) is a 47 year-old female who is requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

3.  Nguyễn Thị B. (20213010036) is a 28 year-old female who is requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

4.  Trần Thị H. (20213010078) is a 33 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the arts sector operating a handicraft business.

5.  Dương Thị D. (20213010079) is a 48 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

6.  Đỗ V.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Lolina

texts.en:
Lolina B. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Lolina is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Lolina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lolina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lolina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolina is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lolina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Bunthoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Bunthoeun T. is 51 years old. She lives in Prek Svay village in Kandal province. She is a house wife and her husband, Mr. Chhoeun Sieng, is a construction worker. This family earns little money to support their needs; however they try to work hard with their business. Mrs. Bunthoeun T. decided to request a loan to buy some supplies for construction to expand the business. She is a mother of five children; one is an employee in a garment factory, two are construction workers, while the other two are studying in local public school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy some supplies for construction.

loans.name: Afde Group No. 5

texts.en:
Ms. Ndeye Arame N. heads AFDE Group No. 5. Aged 60, she has a long experience working in small restaurants. Her aunt on her father's side introduced her to the business, teaching her the trade.

Ms. N. sells breakfast, lunch and dinner and would like to use part of her loan to replenish her stock of poultry and meat. The other part she will invest in her side business: selling hair weaves.

Each member of the group receives 100,000 FCFA for their business. Like Ms. N., Seynabou F. also sells hair weaves; Ms. Fatma F. sells breakfast items (e.g. sandwiches with bean-spread, mayonnaise, eggs, etc.); Ms. Maguath F. sells frozen juices; and Ms. Baba Coumba L. sells fish. 


L'Association des Femmes pour le Developpement d'Entreprises (AFDE: Association of Women for Business Development) is a cooperative of small-scale traders working in Thies, a city about seventy kilometers from Dakar. The Association was founded in 1993 by twenty entrepreneurial women as a cooperative to increase their purchasing power and to organize a tontine. A tontine is a revolving group loan in which each member contributes a small amount to a daily fund, with a different member financed each day.

The tontine has evolved to more formal group loans through UIMCEC. For such loans, the members are split into five-member groups, with a designated president and treasurer. These sub-groups may be the same for many years, but often change members depending on financing needs and other considerations. The AFDE organizes monthly member meetings and runs a cooperative for its members, allowing them to buy rice and other staples at a better price. The association's President is Ms. Mame Diarra Mar.

loans.use: To replenish her stock of poultry and meat

loans.name: Afde Group No. 11

texts.fr:
L’Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l’Entreprise (AFDE) est une organisation de femmes commerçantes de petite échelle travaillant dans Thiès, une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar. L'association a été fondée en 1993 par vingt femmes entrepreneurs pour augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat par le biais  d’une tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). 
Cette politique ne permettant pas de financer au même jour tous les membres, elles décidèrent d’adhérer à l’IMCEC afin de s’octroyer du crédit sans des demandes de garanties. C’est ainsi que les membres sont divisés en  sous groupe de 5, avec une présidente désignée et une trésorière pour chaque sous groupe. Ces sous-groupes, au nombre de 52 en ce moment, peuvent être le même pendant de nombreuses années, mais changent souvent de membres selon le financement des besoins et d'autres considérations.
 L'AFDE organise des réunions de membre mensuellement où tous les sous groupes sont conviés et dirige une coopération pour ses membres, en leur permettant d'acheter du riz et d'autres produits à de meilleurs prix.
 L'AFDE est dirigée par une Présidente du nom de Madame Mame Diarra MAR et une trésorière Madame Ndeye Ndella Diouf toutes habitantes de Thiès. 


Madame Aïssata N. mariée et mère de 4 enfants est la présidente du sous groupe AFDE N°11. Entrée dans le commerce depuis 7 ans  par l’influence d’une amie, Madame N. âgée de 44 ans compte avec son travail augmenter le revenu familial très insuffisant afin de mieux améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants et de sa petite fille de 5 ans qu’elle a en charge depuis sa naissance. Elle vend des marchandises comme des fruits,  jujube …. Elle est dans ce sous groupe avec Madame CoumB. Laobé Bâ vendeuse de thiouraye (encens), Madame CoumB. Kanté vendeuse de charbon de bois, pâte d’arachide, huile de palme, Madame Awa S. vendeuse de produits cosmétiques et de Madame Fatou D. vendeuse de petits déjeuners. C’est dans le cadre de leur commerce qu’elles sollicitent un prêt de 500000 FCFA pour recevoir 100000 FCFA par personne.
texts.en:
The Association of Women for Business Development ( l'Association des Femmes pour le Developpement de l'Entreprise - AFDE) is an organisation of small-scale women traders who work in Thiès, a town which lies 70 kilometers from Dakar. The association was founded in 1993 by twenty female entrepreneurs in order to increase their purchasing power by means of a tontine (a revolving finance system whereby each member contributes periodically an agreed amount and these funds are passed on in rotation to different members). Since this policy does not allow for the financing of all members on the same day, they decided to join l'U-IMCEC (an association of mutual savings and loans institutions) in order to obtain a loan without being asked for guarantees. The members have thus formed sub-groups of five women, with a designated president and a treasurer for each sub-group. These sub-groups, of which there are currently 52, may remain the same for many years, but often change members in line with their needs and other considerations. The AFDE organises monthly members' meetings to which all the sub-groups are invited, and it manages a cooperative for its members, which allows them to buy rice and other products at a better price. The AFDE is run by a president whose name is Mrs. Mame Diarra MAR and a treasurer, Mrs.Ndeye Ndella Diouf, both residents of Thiès. Mrs. Aïssata N., married and mother of four children, is the president of AFDE sub-group N° 11. She has been running a business for the past seven years through the influence of a friend. Mrs. N. is 44 years old. She hopes that her activity will supplement the quite insufficient family income and improve living conditions for her children and her five-year-old grandchild she has under her care since she was born. She sells food products such as fruit, jujube, … Her sub-group also includes: • Mrs. CoumB. Laobé Bâ, who sells thiouraye (incense) • Mrs. CoumB. Kanté, who sells charcoal, peanut butter, palm oil • Mrs. Awa S., who sells beauty products, and • Mrs. Fatou D., who sells breakfasts. They are requesting a loan of 500,000 FCFA for their businesses, which will amount to 100,000 FCFA per person.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen their activities

loans.name: Afde Group No. 10

texts.fr:
L’Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l’Entreprise (AFDE) est une organisation de femmes commerçantes de petite échelle travaillant dans Thiès, une ville située à 70 Kms de Dakar. L'association a été fondée en 1993 par vingt femmes entrepreneurs pour augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat par le biais  d’une tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). Cette politique ne permettant pas de financer au même jour tous les membres, elles décidèrent d’adhérer à l’IMCEC afin de s’octroyer du crédit sans des demandes de garanties. C’est ainsi que les membres sont divisés en  sous groupe de 5, avec une présidente désignée et une trésorière pour chaque sous groupe. Ces sous-groupes, au nombre de 52 en ce moment, peuvent être le même pendant de nombreuses années, mais changent souvent de membres selon le financement des besoins et d'autres considérations.  L'AFDE organise des réunions de membre mensuellement où tous les sous groupes sont conviés et dirige une coopération pour ses membres, en leur permettant d'acheter du riz et d'autres produits à de meilleurs prix.  L'AFDE est dirigée par une Présidente du nom de Madame Mame Diarra MAR et une trésorière Madame Ndeye Ndella Diouf toutes habitantes de Thiès. 

Pour l’AFDE N°10, c’est Madame Ndeye Marie N. qui est la présidente. Elle est vendeuse d’habillements pour femmes et produits cosmétiques. Célibataire sans enfants, Madame N. fait ce commerce depuis 2 ans pour s’auto employer et lutter contre la dépendance financière. Elle compte avec ce crédit acheter de l’habillement pour femmes et des produits cosmétiques en Gambie qu’elle va placer à ses clientes.
Les autres membres du sous groupe sont : Madame Amlnata F. vendeuse d’huile de palme, pâte d’arachides, chaussures et sacs…, Madame Khewe N. vendeuse de poissons séchés et de l’huile de palme, Madame Souadou Dramé vendeuse habillement et parfums et Madame Sokhna N. vendeuse habillement et petit déjeuners. Elles sollicitent au niveau des prêteurs un crédit de 500000 FCFA qu’elles vont se partager à part égale.
texts.en:
The Association of Women for Business Development ( l'Association des Femmes pour le Developpement de l'Entreprise - AFDE) is an organisation of small-scale women traders who work in Thiès, a town which lies 70 kilometers from Dakar. The association was founded in 1993 by twenty female entrepreneurs in order to increase their purchasing power by means of a tontine (a revolving finance system whereby each member contributes periodically an agreed amount and these funds are passed on in rotation to different members). Since this policy does not allow for the financing of all members on the same day, they decided to join l'U-IMCEC (an association of mutual savings and loans institutions) in order to obtain a loan without being asked for guarantees. The members have thus formed sub-groups of five women, with a designated president and a treasurer for each sub-group. These sub-groups, of which there are currently 52, may remain the same for many years, but often change members in line with their needs and other considerations. The AFDE organises monthly members' meetings to which all the sub-groups are invited, and it manages a cooperative for its members, which allows them to buy rice and other products at a better price. The AFDE is run by a president whose name is Mrs. Mame Diarra MAR and a treasurer, Mrs.Ndeye Ndella Diouf, both residents of Thiès. The president of AFDE No. 10 is Mrs Ndeye Marie N.. She sells womens' clothing and cosmetic products. Single without any children, Mrs. N. has been carrying out this business for two years in order to be self-employed and to fight against financial dependence. With this loan she is planning to buy women's clothing and cosmetic products in the Gambia and she will sell these to her customers. The other members of the sub-group are: Mrs. Aminata F., who sells palm oil, peanut butter, shoes and bags; Mrs. Khewe N., who sells dried fish and palm oil; Mrs. Souadou Dramé, who sells clothing and perfumes; and Mrs. Sokhna N., who sells clothing and breakfasts. They are applying for a loan of 500,000 FCFA from the lenders and will divide this equally between them.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen their business

loans.name: Nguyễn
loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide services.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma D. is from the village of Camiguin. She is 52 years old. Erma is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Erma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Erma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Erma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erma is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Erma from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Robai

texts.en:
Robai K. S. is forty years old, a widowed lady with five children aged between twenty-five and ten years. Her business is located at Serem in Kakamega and is situated in a busy market. For the last nine years she has been engaged in selling tomatoes, 'sukumawiki' (a popular green vegetable), onions and cabbages.

She also sells charcoal and firewood. She is using her loan to buy maize, beans, and charcoal to expand her business.

She sells her products to the local people and the major challenge she has is so many people engaging in the same kind of business as hers, thus customers have too many merchants to choose from. There are also debtors who have problems paying for the goods gotten on credit from her. However, she works very hard to make ends meet and she hopes to be supplying wholesale. She dreams of educating her children and building a nice residential house.

loans.use: Maize, beans, and charcoal for resale

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en: T. Nguyễn V. (20201060032) is a 47-year-old male living in the town of Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. He is married and has two school-aged children. T. owns and operates a business providing food services to local community members. He has been engaged in this business for over twelve years and earns approximately 5,300,000 VND a month. In 2008, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding his business. T. is now requesting a new loan of 7,840,000 VND which will again be used to invest in expanding his business. The loan will be his 3rd from SEDA. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** T. Nguyễn V. (20201060032) là 47 tuổi nam. Anh ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Anh ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học. Để kiếm sống, T. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ thực phẩm cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương. T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 12 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 5,300,000 VND một tháng. Vào 2008, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ T. chính giúp cải thiện điều kiện và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. T. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Anh ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7,840,000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. T. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ T. chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Phy

texts.en:
Mrs. Phy P. is 56 years old. She lives in Neasar Kiri village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 10 hectares of land on which she cultivates rice.  Phy is also a beef seller.  She is the mother of two children who attend a local public school. Her husband, Mr. Koemphan Kuy, is the village president and also a construction worker.

This family faces a problem because their rice field is far from an irrigation system, so there is not enough water to support their crop, nor do they have enough money to buy the pump they need. So Mrs. Phy P. decided to apply for a loan to buy a pump to increase their rice yield this year.

loans.use: To buy a pump

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria P. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Victoria is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Victoria owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $88 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

To make a living, N. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale.  N. has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately $163 a month from this activity.

In 2008, N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities.  N. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.  

N. is now requesting a new loan of 7.804.000 VND which also will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.  The will be his 3rd loan from SEDA.  N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.name: Phallay

texts.en:
Mrs. Phallay C. is a villager in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She is 27 years old. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice to support her family, Her husband, Mr. Ny Neat, is a duck breeder. 

This family faces a problem because their field is far from an irrigation system, so there is not enough water. They have neither enough money to support the rice field nor to start a new business. Her husband is good at breeding animals, and this would be another business for them. 

Thus, Mrs. Phallay C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump and also to purchase some piglets for breeding. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in primary school, while the other two are too young to go to school or to work.

loans.use: To buy a pump and some piglets

loans.name: Step By Step Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Beat is 32 years old and married with five children between the ages of 7 and 15. They are all in school. She also takes care of three additional dependents. 

Beat has a beauty salon business in Wantoni Mukono that has been operational for fifteen years. From her transactions, she is able to make about $52 in profit every week. Her business is mostly seasonal, during festive seasons and also during weekends, but all the same, she manages to attract her customers and so she is able to make some savings.

Beat has a dream of opening up other big salons with branches in various towns, as well as to build a family house and rentals for her family. She needs a loan to be able to buy hair treatments, hair oil and chemicals, and also to pay salon rent. She is such a hard-working lady.

loans.use: to buy hair treatments, hair oil and chemicals, and to pay salon rent.

loans.name: Mẫn

texts.en:

To make a living, L. operates a restaurant, serving breakfast foods to customers in the local community.  L. has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately $233 a month from this activity.


In 2008, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant.  

L. is now requesting a new loan of 7.804.000 VND, which again will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant.  This will be her 3rd loan from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

loans.name: Chany

texts.en:
Mrs. Chany S. is a villager in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province. She is 29 years old. She is a farmer who owns 1.5 hetares of land for cultivating rice to support her family. She is the mother of one child who is too small to go to school or work.

Her husband, Mr. Soeun Nget, is a duck breeder. This family faces a problem because they purchased rice on credit for duck food. They tried to earn some money to pay for it, but they were not able to pay the creditor. Thus, Mrs. Chany S. decided to request a loan to pay for the rice food for the ducks.

To make a living, Veneranda owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Veneranda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $88 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Veneranda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Akwata Empola Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Kevina is a hard working and devoted lady. She is divorced with four children, all in primary school.

Kevina has operated a restaurant in Kyetawo for three years now. She started her restaurant with very limited capital and only boosted her business with the help of a loan from Pearl Microfinance. She is now able to make about $37 a week in profits. Kevina says that she is successful because of being kind to her clients and being faithful to good customer care.

She has a dream of educating all her children to the University level, plus being successful both in business and with her family. She needs a loan to be able to buy more foodstuffs and sauces for her restaurant, plus giving it a new face with new paints this year.

loans.use: Buying more food stuffs and renovating her restaurant for better services.

loans.name: Mẫn

texts.en:
H. Mẫn Thị is a 45-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has two adult -aged children.  To make a living, H. operates a family member's business venture in the arts sector, selling wood handicrafts to tourists and local community members.  H. has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately $94 a month from this activity.


In 2008, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. 

H. is now requesting a new loan of 4.704.000 VND, which again will be used to purchase raw materials.  This will be her 3rd loan from SEDA.  H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


H. Mẫn Thị (20201060034) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành.  Để kiếm sống, H. Tham gia công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nghệ thuật.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hàng thủ công mỹ nghệ.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán hàng mỹ nghệ bằng gỗ cho du khách và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 1.600.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2008, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  H. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất hàng mỹ nghệ bổ sung.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.704.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất hàng mỹ nghệ bổ sung.  Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  H. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Marpie

texts.en:
Mrs. Marpie F. is 36 years old, married, and lives in Sta. Cruz, Tangub City. She is married to Gregorio F., a farm caretaker, who earns an average wage together with her picture is her son. With their income, they experienced hardship in raising a family of four children. Therefore, five months ago, Marpie decided to open a small sari-sari (variety) store inside her home (as pictured, together with her little children). Now, she has established a small stall in front of the house and presently earns an average net income of not less than 3,500 PHP, which is so helpful for their family. 
Marpie joined Kiva partner PMPC because she was very interested in its various products and services. With good credit performance from her first loan, she was given the privilege of borrowing 8,000 PHP as her second loan. She will use this loan to add to her capital for her sari-sari store and as capital for her dried fish vending business. She is hoping that her business will make more progress and that, some day, she will be able to send her children to school, even to college, with her business profits.

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store and dried fish vending business

location.town: Sta. Cruz, Tangub, City, Misamis Occidental, Minda

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is involved in rice farming. She is 38 years old and married. She works hard to be able to keep up with her family’s growing needs especially for her children’s education. She is now preparing her land for planting. Helen wants to make sure rice crops will grow well in her farm. She has applied for a loan of Php8, 000 from CEVI to supply her needs to buy farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Chann Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Chann Thoeun H. lives in Slaeng village in Takeo province. She is 40 years old. She is a farmer who owns 3-hetar of land to cultivate rice and support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phan Keam, owns a harvesting machine which he rents to people in the local village at harvest time. In this rice field, this family faces some problems. Their field is far from an irrigation system. There is not enough water, yet they did not have enough money to acquire water to support the rice field.  Mrs. Chann Thoeun H. has decided to ask for a loan to dig a well and the rest of the loan she wants to buy fertilizers, and pesticides. She is a mother of three children. Two are studying at th  local public school while the other one is a laborer in a garment factory.

loans.use: To dig a well

loans.name: Bugoba Group, Mukono

texts.en: K. Justine is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 26 years old and married with one child aged 3 years. She has a bar business in Seeta that she has been running for some time now and she is grateful that with the help of loans. K. Justine is now able to make 140,000 as weekly profits which was not the case before the loans. Justine sells beer, sodas, wines and other brews and she hopes to expand her business further to be able to make more profits. Justine needs a loan to be able to restock her bar with more crates of beer, soda, mineral water and wines.

loans.use: Buying more crates of wines, beer and sodas for resale.

loans.name: Anunciacion

texts.en:
Anunciacion is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She joined in July 2009 and is thankful for the financial service that she has gained access to. A 57-year old married woman, she spends most of her time working on the farm. Anunciacion started planting rice way back in 1990. 

She has six children and some of them are already married. Right now, her farm is being prepared for planting. She is in need of farm supplies like seeds, fertilizers and others. She has applied for a loan of Php 8, 0000 to acquire the necessary farm supplies that she needs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Merlyn E., 50 years of age, is married and is a resident of Purok 6 Garang, Tangub City. She is married to Armando who is a farmer who manages their own riceland in their barangay (village). They are also receiving daily income from rental of their motorcycle for hire.

In order to help her husband financially, Merlyn decided to engage in a business. She opened a sari-sari (general) store and for five years already she has been able to maintain this business. Now she is earning an average net income of not less than P3,500 per month which is very helpful in meeting the basic daily needs of her family.

Merlyn maintained a good credit performance with her first loan and so she has been given the privilege of obtaining P10,000 as her second loan to add to the capital of her sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used for loan repayment and as savings for their children's education.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
N. Batchuluun is 51 years old and lives with his wife and two teenage sons in a house in the Arhangai province of central Mongolia. His wife works at a private company and both boys attend a local high school and help Batchuluun with his business.

Since 2000, Batchuluun has operated a household goods retail business and currently his working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs. In 2005, he began operating in a shipping container in the local market in addition to a small rented stand. Batchuluun has done well with his business because he takes note of what his customers want from him and, if he doesn't have it, he makes sure that he gets the products on his next purchasing trip.

Batchuluun would like to increase his capital in the future and better his family's quality of life. He is requesting a 3,200,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of household goods related the the Tsaagansar, or Lunar New Year, celebrations.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of household goods

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita D. is from the village of Olingan. She is 61 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Teresita owns and operates a business raising crops, planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,800 PHP a month. In 2006, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to finance her vegetable business and to invest in pig raising. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions, especially to cover daily expenditures. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To finance her vegetable business and to invest in pig-raising

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene S. lives in Labo, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old, is married, and is the mother of two children, one of whom is shown with her in the photo.

Eugene owns and operates a sari-sari (general) store. She has been engaged in this kind of business and earns approximately Php 2,000 a month.

In 2006, Eugene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of Php 7,000 from PMPC.

Eugene is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta’s family depends on their one-hectare farm. She and her husband work hand-in-hand in tilling the land to plant rice crops. She has seven children with 21 years old as the oldest. She said that despite the difficulties she experiences in her business, she still keeps herself happy and thankful that she has a source of income.

Julieta is now asking to borrow Php 8,000 from CEVI. This loan will be used to fund her farm. She will be able to buy farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizer, and others.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Nezikokolima Group, Mukono

texts.en:
S. Grace is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 38 years old and married with two children, aged 20 and 14, both still in secondary section. She also takes care of three dependents.

Grace has a poultry business where she keeps both broilers and layers for meat and eggs respectively, and in the near future, Grace hopes to expand her farm to have more chickens that will bring in more revenue. At this time, Grace needs a loan to be able to buy more chicken feed for her farm as well as booking more day-old chicks for farm expansion, using the loan in addition to the savings that she has. This will enable her to take good care of her family as well as pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Booking more day-old chicks and stocking more chicken feed

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
S. Narantsetseg is a 51-year-old woman who lives with her 21-year-old son in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her son live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the 'ger' districts on the outskirts of the city. Her son operates a taxi service and dog-breeding service while Narantsetseg operates a sewing and tailoring business. She worked as a tailor in a private company from 1980 until 1995 in Darhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. 

She began her own tailoring business in 2000 and currently has 1,000,000 tugrug working capital with monthly sales of approximately 600,000 tugrugs. Her profits are between 250,000 and 300,000 tugrugs per month and she would like to expand her business and grow these profits in the future. She says, "I would like to purchase newer styles of cloth for my business so that I can attract new customers." Narantsetseg is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (approx. $1,031 USD) loan in order to purchase fabrics for her business and in order to build a shelter for dogs for her son's business.

loans.use: to purchase silk and fabrics

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia L. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Eufemia is widowed and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Eufemia owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Eufemia is just starting this business.

In 2009, Eufemia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eufemia is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Eufemia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ernelita

texts.en: Ernelita grew up on a farm because her parents are farmers. She learned farming from them. She is now 45 years old, married, and has eleven children. She is also a farmer now. She cultivates her land for rice crops, like most of the farmers in her town in Agusan Del Sur. When she learned about CEVI, she immediately joined to gain access to financial opportunities. She is now requesting a loan of Php 8,000. She will use this loan to fund her farm. She will buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs she needs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie J. is from the city of Oroquieta. She is 41 years old, married, and is the mother of two.

The family earns a living raising pigs and selling them to the neighborhood. The business has run for about two years and earns approximately Php 5,000 a month.

Josie applied for membership in PMPC for her financial needs and has since maintained a good repayment record. Now she is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her pig-raising business. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She want to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feed, and vitamins to make the pigs grow faster and healthier

loans.name: Sokunthy

texts.en:
Mr. Sokunthy M. lives in Krang Roung village in Takeo province. He is 35 years old and is the father of three children: two are enrolled in the local public school while the other one is too small to go to school or to work. His wife is shown on the right in the photo.

Mr. Sokunthy M. and his wife, Mrs. Theavy Sorm, are farmers who own a small piece of land on which they cultivate rice to support their family living.

This family can earn only a little money from their rice field to support their family living, however hard they try to work. Mr. Sokunthy M. has a plantation to start new business but he does not have enough money to start it. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to purchase some supplies such as an ice cream container and ice cream to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase an ice cream container and ice cream to sell

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa, 27 years old, is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She is involved in rice farming. She learned farming through her parents. She and her husband are currently preparing their land for planting. She borrowed 8,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner, to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers to be supplied at the farm. Receiving this loan is truly helpful to Marissa’s business as she aims for an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Suren

texts.en:
B. Suren is 45 years old and lives with her husband and 18-year-old daughter in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family lives in a 'ger', or traditional nomadic tent, on the outskirts of the city. Her daughter attends a local high school, her husband works as a driver for a private company, and Suren operates a retail clothing stall in Bumbugur market. She began her business in 2006 and currently has working capital exceeding 3,000,000 tugrugs with her monthly sales approximately 1,300,000 tugrugs. She makes a monthly profit of between 200,000 and 300,000 tugrugs, and her business is now completely sustainable.

Suren is good at managing money and says, "I'm saving money in order to pay my daughter's tuition". She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan (approx. $1,375 USD) in order to increase her working capital and to purchase clothing to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more apparel for her business

loans.name: Jahantab Group

texts.en:
This is Jahantab Group which is made up of five female members. These women wish to take a group loan of 70,000 Afghani.

Gulaly who is 35, has a business doing embroidery work. She is married with four children, all students. With the loan, she would like to expand her business as she would like to support her husband and her children.

The second member is Meher who is a bead worker. She started this business during the Taliban regime because at that time women had no choice to go outside to work. Thus she decided to start the bead-work business in her home to support her husband and her children.

Afghani is the third member and she would like to receive a loan for her brother who is a taxi driver. With the loan he needs to change the engine of his taxi.

Saltanat would like to take a loan for her husband who has a cart from which he sells chips with burgers. He is a hardworking man and works seven days a week. With the loan he wants to buy more essential materials for his business.

The last member of this group is Latifa who wants to take a loan for her husband who has a shop selling cosmetics. He would like to progress his business and buy more cosmetics.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en: 29-year-old Marivel is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is only 8 years old. She works hard to be able to earn and save for her children’s future. Like any mother, she also wants to improve her family’s living condition. She has sought the help of MFIs in the Philippines. She is now a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She is currently applying for a loan of Php 8,000, which she will use for the farm. With this loan, she can now acquire farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer and also pay the laborers she hires to help at the farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Zinunula Group, Mukono

texts.en: M. Janet is a member of the Zinunula group, Mukono. She is a hard-working lady with a retail shop in Nasuuti. She is 27 years old and married with three children. She also takes care of her parents back in the village. Janet says that her biggest challenge in business are the debtors who always take goods on credit and fail or take too long to pay, hence affecting her cash flow. Janet needs a loan to be able to stock her shop with more sugar, salt, cooking oil, bread, sweets and other confectioneries since the profits made will help her save to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en: Mrs. Yoem P. lives in Dei Chrab village in Takeo province. She is 66 years old. She is a widow who has a child. Her child is a driver. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare to cultivate rice on to support her family. This family can not earn much income; however, they try to work with their rice field. So Mrs. Yoem P. has a plan to start breeding animals but they have only a little money to start up this new business. Thus, Mrs. Yoem P. decided to request a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Ulziinasan

texts.en:
C. Ulziinasan is a 32-year-old widow who lives with her 5-year-old son in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Ulziinasan operates a food retail business in two rented stands in Dalaihuu market. Her business has been in operation since 2000 and her working capital is currently around 2,000,000 tugrugs. Her daily sales are between 120,000 and 160,000 tugrugs and her monthly profits are between 290,000 and 300,000 tugrugs.

Because of her monthly profits, good business experience, and loyal customers, Ulziinasan has been able to provide for her son after her husband's sudden death last spring. The mother and son live in their own 'ger', or Mongolian nomadic tent, in their own yard on the outskirts of the city. Ulziinasan hopes to keep growing her business in the future and therefore she is requesting an 800,000 tugrugs loan (approx. $550 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of food to sell.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of food

loans.name: Guadalufe

texts.en: Guadalufe is a rice farmer. She is 47 years old, married and has three children. Her oldest child is now 27 years old. As a farmer, it is necessary that she work hard to maintain the farm that’s why she makes sure to be healthy and strong. She hopes to grow her business so she applied to CEVI to expand her business opportunities. She applied for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en: Ludivina D. is from the village of Gango, city of Ozamiz. Ludivina is expanding her business and is requesting additional working capital for her "sari-sari" (variety)  store and vegetable selling business.  Ludivina has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns a promising 4000 Philippine pesos a month. Ludivina has applied for and had a loan funded by Kiva for several times already. She has maintained a good repayment record and so she enjoys the privileges of a member in good standing. She deeply wishes to preserve her membership with PMPC so she can continue to rely on them to serve her financial needs.

loans.use: As working capital for a "sari-sari" (variety)  store and vegetable selling business.

loans.name: Edelberta Badiang's Group

texts.en:
Edelberta B. is from the village of San Vicente. She is 61 years old. Edelberta is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Edelberta B.'s Group.

Edelberta is married and has nine adult-aged children. To make a living, Edelberta plants & harvests rice for sale. Edelberta has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Edelberta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edelberta has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Edelberta is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure & insecticide. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Edelberta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer & insecticide

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en: Purevsuren is 53 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. His wife works as a nurse at the local hospital. His 21-year-old daughter and his son are in high school. Purevsuren is a trained carpenter who started his wooden furniture business in 1992 and has been steadily growing his business in the 18 years since. When he began his business, Purevsuren's working capital was approximately 100,000 tugrugs (approx. $70 USD). However, with a lot of hard work and good business practices his working capital is currently approximately 1,618,000 tugrugs (approx. $1,110 USD). Using his business profits, he was able to purchase a large Korean truck to use not only in transporting his goods, but also in earning money as a transportation service for other people. Purevsuren is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 tugrugs in order to purchase more wood and tools to keep his carpentry business growing.

loans.use: To purchase wood and tools

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl A. is from the village of Owaon. She is 32 years old. Cheryl is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cheryl raises chickens and pigs for sale. Cheryl has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP average per month for these activities.

In 2008, Cheryl joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase feed & other supplies for the poultry raising activity. Cheryl is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed and supplies for the chickens and pigs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Cheryl from PMPC, and this is her second time in KIVA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially the educational expenses of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feeds & other supplies

loans.name: Mirembe Kikooza Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Annet is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 39 years old and a widow with five children aged 25 to 27 years of age.  She also takes care of her parents.  Annet has a bar business in Kikooza that she has been running for eight years and she is grateful that with the help of loans, she is able to make 210,000 Ugandan shillings as weekly profits which was not the case before the loans.

Annet sells beer, soda, wine and other brews and she hopes to expand her business further to be able to make more profits that will enable her build her own house as well as continue educating her children. Annet needs a loan to be able to restock her bar with more crates of beer, soda, mineral water and wines.

(N. Annet is pictured in the small inset photo. She is also in the group photo, but she cannot be clearly seen. A few members of the group are not pictured.)

loans.use: Restocking a bar with more beer, soda and other drinks.

loans.name: Pipule Money Group

texts.en:
These are members of "Pipule Money" group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the city of Makeni, northern Sierra Leone. These women want a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to boost their businesses. With such a loan, they can add more goods to their businesses. This will attract more customers, sales will improve, and consequently they can improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is 31-year-old Augusta, on the right in the photo. A mother of 4 children, she is married to a miner. Augusta’s children are attending school – 1 in secondary school, 2 in primary school; the last is not of school-going age. Augusta sells fried cakes and gara lappers (locally dyed cloth, sometimes with fabricated designs). She has been in this business for 6 years now.  With her share of this loan, she will buy a bag of flour, gallons of cooking oil, bags of sugar, and baking powder.

loans.use: Buy a bag of flour, gallons of cooking oil, bags of sugar, and baking powder

loans.name: Sayed Rahman Group

texts.en:
The pictured Group is Sayed Rahman group which has two members. These two entrepreneurs would like to make their businesses bigger and to complete the requirements of their businesses.

Sayed Rahman, who has a general store, is the group leader. He is 55 and the father of six children. He works in his shop together with his oldest son. With the loan he wants to buy more materials to progress his business and to attract more clients to his shop.

Shah Gul has a quilt-sewing business. She is famous for her work in her area and most of the people like her way of work. Mostly the ones who are having a wedding party come to her and request her to sew beautiful kinds of quilt for the bride.

Together,  Sayed Rahman and Shah Gul have requested a group loan of 15,000 Afghani. They both would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more materials for his store

loans.name: Leap's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of twelve people, is located in Tradak Pong village in Takeo province. Mrs. Leap C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members, and each of them will use the loan for a different purpose. 

Leap is a farmer who owns 3-hectares of land where she cultivates rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sok Chan, is a construction worker.  

Mrs. Leap C. faces a problem with her rice field because it has infertile soil, but she doesn't have enough money to support it. So she decided to request a loan to purchase fertilizers and additional pesticides. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are construction workers, while the third is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Tuyatsetseg

texts.en:
Tuyatsetseg is 34 years old and lives with her husband and 5-year-old daughter in the Arhangai province of central Mongolia. The family lives together in their own wooden house. Her daughter attends a local kindergarten, and Tuyatsetseg and her husband both work in the family's businesses.

They began their dairy product retail business in 2008 with working capital of 1,350,000 MNT. In this business, she and her husband would travel across their province and purchase dairy products from producers and sell these products for a profit in their town. 

Because of their success with the dairy business, Tuyatsetseg was able to start a taxi service. Her husband operates the dairy business and she operates the taxi service. Because of this couple's hard work and determination, they were able to purchase their current house and yard.

They hope to have continued success in both businesses and will keep working hard in order to improve their family's life. Tuyatsetseg is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of dairy products in order to sell during the upcoming Lunar New Year celebrations.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of dairy products

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr: A. A. Gisèle est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ZINSOU Clétus, un couturier, Gisèle est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Tous les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. Il y a 1 an que la famille s’est installée à Kowégbo à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Gisèle s’est arrêtée au cours secondaire. Gisèle excelle dans la commercialisation des produits vivriers, notamment le maïs. Gisèle vend également de l’huile d’arachide, ce qui lui permet de multiplier ses sources de revenu. Gisèle a une boutique au quartier N’Vènamédé, où elle vend ses produits. C’est à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin, à Kétou et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Gisèle s’approvisionne. Gisèle est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits dans l’institution. Tous ces crédits ont été bien remboursés. Très sollicitée par sa clientèle, Gisèle ambitionne renforcer son capital et élargir son champ d’activité, afin de mieux faire face à la demande sans cesse croissante. C'est la raison pour laquelle Gisèle sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Gisele A. A. was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Cletus Zinsou, a tailor, and is the mother of four children, all of whom go to school. All children live together with their parents. In addition to their own children, the couple also takes care of another child. A year ago the family settled in Kowegbo, a neighborhood in Cotonou. Husband and wife take care of the family expenses together. Gisele’s schooling stopped at the secondary level. She is an excellent vendor of food crops, especially corn. She also sells peanut oil, which allows her to increase her sources of revenue. She keeps a shop in the area of N’Venamede, where she sells her products. Gisele purchases her products in Parakou (in the North of Benin), in Ketou and in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a long-time client of ALIDé and has previously obtained five loans. All these loans have been duly repaid. Gisele has a good client base and would like to boost her capital and increase the scope of her operations, in order to better meet the ever growing demand. This is why she is requesting her sixth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 16 bags of corn, 100 kg (50 lbs) each

loans.name: Ffena Tugagawale Group, Mukono

texts.en:
J. Muhammed is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 42 years old and married with three children between the ages of 18 and 12, and he also takes care of two orphans. 

Muhammed has operated a business of selling old shoes and clothes from Kame Valley market for 16 years, from which he is able to make about $25 in weekly profits. His biggest challenge is the limited capital at his disposal. 

Muhammed has a dream of building his own house so that he can stop renting. He also wants to educate all his children to the University level with the hope that they will find better job opportunities. He needs a loan to be able to buy more shoes and clothes for resale.

loans.use: Buying more stock of clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Setha's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Setha N. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members, each of whom will use the loan for a different purpose. This village bank loan, which consists of seventeen members, is located in Tradak Pong village in Takeo province.

Setha is the mother of three children, two of whom are laborers in a garment factory, while the third is studying in the local public school. She is a vegetable seller, and her husband, Mr. Sym Orm, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to support his family. 

This family has a problem because their house is too old to live in, so they must built a new house. However, they have little money to build this house, so Setha decided to apply for a loan to buy additional bricks. 

All seventeen of the members are shown in the photo, but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy additional bricks

loans.name: Ffena Tugagawale Group 1, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Kanaabi is 40 years old and a single mother with six children, four of whom are still in school. 

N. has been running a business of selling produce, mostly matooke (steamed green plantain), from Kame Valley for 25 years. Ever since she started using loans in her business, she is able to make about $208 a week in profits. 

She is thankful to her creditors because she is able to have enough stock on hand for her customers all the time, hence making more sales and more money. She hopes to expand her business further by offering additional products.  

With this loan that N. is seeking, she hopes to restock her business with more matooke, as well as to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Buying more matooke for resale and paying school fees for her children.

loans.name: Maha

texts.en: Maha is a 45-year-old married woman and mother of three. She opened a clothes shop in 2008 to help her husband support the household. Today, Maha is requesting a loan of $1,000 to expand her inventory and offer a wider choice of clothes and new collections to her clients.

loans.use: to expand her inventory

loans.name: Poeng

texts.en: Poeng L. is a seller whose main activity is selling cooking ingredients. She started in the grocery business in the beginning of 2005. She has a partner in her husband, who helps feed the family by fishing in the river. This couple is married and has been blessed with two children, who are working in the garment industry. To get extra income, Poeng L. is taking out her loan to buy more groceries to sell. Poeng L. was not available when the photo was taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 25-year-old single man who helps his father support the household. He has owned an electric car repair shop in his town since 2006. Today, Ibrahim is asking for a loan of $1,200 to expand his business by buying new tools needed.

loans.use: to expand his business by buying new tools needed

loans.name: Piosi

texts.en: Piosi A. A. is sixty-two years old, married, and has eight children--three boys and five girls. His wife does maize farming for home consumption and also for selling on a small scale. For the last five years, Piosi has been engaged in two types of businesses in a busy market at Serem in Kakamega. Most of the time, he likes spending time rearing his livestock and sells the milk he gets from his cows to the local shopkeepers and the hotels. He also has a timber business where he sells timber to the local people. Particularly, he is using his loan to buy timber to sell. He hopes to set up a timber yard in the future to grow his business and also buy more grade cows to supply more milk. Piosi has a dream to give quality education to his children and buy a plot where he will be able to build a residential house. He is very hardworking, talented and generous.

loans.use: To buy timber to sell

loans.name: Zeba Jan Group

texts.en: The pictured group is Zeba Jan, which has four members. Najia, who is the group leader has taken this loan for her husband. She lives in distict 11th of Kabul Afghanistan. She lives in a family of 7 members. She is married having 5 childern.They are all students at school. Her husband has a workshop in which he repairs cars. He is a hard working man and he works seven days of the week in order to receive money and to send his childern to a better school.  With the loan, he would like to buy the essential tools for his shop to attract more clients and to have good monthly income. He is confident that will do his repayments of time and will apply for the other cycle loan soon. She and her husband hope that their business will be a survice for the community.

loans.use: purchasing tools and parts of car

loans.name: Iganga Development Group, Mukono

texts.en: Irene M. is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 25 years old and married with three children aged one, three, and five. Irene operates a grocery store which also sells poultry, shoes and clothes. She is a hard-working young lady with a strong drive to succeed; she was able to repay her first loan easily and is grateful for the benefit it provided. Irene now needs a loan to expand her inventory as well as to buy chicken feed for her broilers, which she also keeps to feed her family.

loans.use: Restocking her various businesses so that they could bring in more profits.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Since 2001, Ali has owned a car repair shop servicing his town and its surroundings. He supports his family with his business. There is great demand for his services.  He is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy spare parts in bulk at wholesale in order to meet his clients' demands and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Thong

texts.en: Thong K., 52, was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She has four children, two of whom are married and the other two are single. All of the children are employed at different jobs. To earn a living, Thong K. cultivates rice and some vegetable crops, which she will sell to buyers when they are matured. A problem she currently faces is that she doesn’t have enough supplies to perform her business. She is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, crop seeds, and other essential accessories for her crop growing activities.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, crop seeds, and other essential accessories.

loans.name: Em's Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan, which consists of twenty one people, is located in Trapeang Chrey village in Takeo province. Mrs. Em P. is the village bank president who was selected by the members. They all will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Em P. is 61 years old. She is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support her family. As a sideline, she is a Khmer cake maker. Although the family works hard with their rice field, they earn little income, so they want to start breeding pigs, but they do not have enough money to buy them. Thus, Mrs. Em P. decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food. She is a mother of two children - one is a laborer in a garment factory while the other is a farmer.

loans.use: To buy some piglets

loans.name: Mohamad Saleh
